body_text.text: Glucokinase (GK) plays a fundamental role in glucose homeostasis by controlling the rate of glucose metabolism in many tissues. GK is believed to function as the primary glucose sensor in a range of neuro/endocrine sentinel cells (including β-cells) that are involved in glucose homeostasis. In pancreatic β-cells, GK acts as a sensor for glucose stimulated insulin release and in hepatocytes it catalyzes the first step of glucose metabolism. The relationship between changes in GK activity and fasting plasma glucose in humans with GK diseases has been well established for both loss and gain of function mutations [233].
body_text.section: Antidiabetic Effects of Glucokinase Activators ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Such strong biological rationale for targeting GK as a potential anti diabetic therapy led to the discovery of small molecule allosteric GK activators (GKAs). GKAs bind to an allosteric site 2 nm away from the bound glucose site and act as non-essential mixed-type enzyme activators [234].
body_text.section: Antidiabetic Effects of Glucokinase Activators ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Animal studies have demonstrated that when the glucokinase gene is disrupted, mice die within days of birth from severe diabetes. Heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the glucokinase gene can result in maturity onset diabetes of the young – type 2, which is linked to defective insulin secretion. The over-expression of glucokinase results in decreased basal blood glucose levels, as well as resistance to developing type 2 diabetes. Evidence suggests that the glucose lowering effects in rodents are mediated by dual effects on increasing plasma insulin levels and suppression of hepatic glucose production as assessed by a pancreatic clamp. Early data in humans suggests that GKAs offer a promising new therapeutic approach to treat type 2 diabetes [235].
body_text.section: Antidiabetic Effects of Glucokinase Activators ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Ro-28-1675 was the first GKA noted to reduce blood glucose after an oral glucose tolerance test in several models of type 2 diabetes in rodents. This compound also lowered basal glucose in diet-induced obese mice accompanying with a rise in insulin levels. Ro-28-1675 attenuated endogenous glucose production and elevated hepatic glucose disposal [236].
body_text.section: Antidiabetic Effects of Glucokinase Activators ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Several GKAs are presently at various stages of clinical development [235]. Roche was the first pharmaceutical company to bring a GKAs into clinical trials. However, Roche’s GKAs were discontinued from further development; the reasons have not been disclosed.
body_text.section: Antidiabetic Effects of Glucokinase Activators ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: AstraZeneca, OSI/Prosidion in conjunction with Eli Lilly, and Merck have been in and are continuing phase II investigations for PSN010. AZD6370 is presently undergoing phase II trials and is being developed for the potential treatment of obesity and type 2 diabetes [237]. Other compounds are presently in phase I and II clinical trials (Table 6), based on their strong in vitro and in vivo preclinical data [238]. For instance, ID1101 enhanced glucose-stimulated insulin release from pancreatic islet cells and glucose disposition by the liver, thereby reducing blood glucose and body weight.
body_text.section: Antidiabetic Effects of Glucokinase Activators ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Preclinical results of compound NN9101 showed good glucose regulation, no weight gain and increased insulin content in pancreas. Its glucose-lowering effect was also observed in first human data, including reduction in both fasting and postprandial glucose. TTP399, which is also in preclinical development, belongs to a chemical class different from that of NN9101. A potent GK activator [239], ARRY403 showed significant blunting of the postprandial glucose excursion in acute OGTT dose–response study in C57BL/6J normal mice. It also reduced both nonfasted and postprandial glucose in ob/ob mice, in ZDF female rats and NONcNZO10/LtJ mice, without causing hypoglycemia or abnormal weight gain. It is now ready to enter human clinical trials. Another potent activator of human GK in vitro, ARRY588 presented glucose-lowering activity in a dose–response OGTT study in C57BI/6J mice [239] and in ob/ob mice [240].
body_text.section: Antidiabetic Effects of Glucokinase Activators ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Although the preclinical and early phase 1 studies suggest promise for these agents, further studies will be needed to elucidate efficacy, safety and tolerability in large numbers of patients in clinical trials.
body_text.section: Antidiabetic Effects of Glucokinase Activators ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Fasting hyperglycemia in diabetes is well correlated with accelerated hepatic glucose production in type 2 diabetes patients; free fatty acids also induce gluconeogenesis [241]. In animal studies, it has been shown that glucose production in the liver can be inhibited both by substances that act directly on gluconeogenesis and by substances that inhibit fatty-acid oxidation. Therefore, inhibition of both free fatty acid release (such as by SDZ WAG 994) and fatty-acid oxidation (such as by β-aminobetaine [emeriamine]) in the liver may be efficient modalities of treatment to prevent fasting hyperglycemia in diabetics [242]. Benfluorex, a derivative of fenfluramine, lowers plasma glucose by inhibition of gluconeogenesis [242]. Inhibition of fructose 1, 6 bisphosphatase, the key hepatic enzyme in gluconeogenesis is also a therapeutic target for treatment of type 2 diabetes [243]. Specific inhibitors of this enzyme (such as [MB06322 (CS-017) discontinued in phase II] and MB07803 in Phase IIa of development by Metabasis Therapeutics) may be useful in type 2 diabetes [244].
body_text.section: Gluconeogenesis Inhibitors ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: The prospect of a non-injectable means of insulin delivery has always been very attractive. There have been a number of pharmaceutical approaches to developing a non-invasive delivery route for insulin, most of them topical (e.g. patches) or inhalation [245]. These share the same weakness as injectable insulin: the delivered protein passes first into the peripheral circulation and only thereafter, in much diluted form, into the liver. Thus, topically and subcutaneously administered insulin result in fat and muscle being exposed to higher insulin levels than the liver. This is in contrast to endogeneous insulin which is delivered from the pancreas into the portal system and the liver. Oral delivery would share this advantage.
body_text.section: Oral Insulin ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: The potential market for an oral form of insulin is assumed to be enormous, thus many laboratories have attempted to devise ways of moving enough intact insulin from the gut to the portal vein to have a measurable effect on blood sugar.
body_text.section: Oral Insulin ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: The various challenges associated with the production of a reliable insulin formulation for oral delivery includes (1) maintaining storage stability of the active protein, (2) avoiding enzymatic degradation in the gastrointestinal tract and (3) overcoming poor spontaneous insulin permeability through the gastrointestinal system. Despite the multiple technical challenges many biopharmaceutical companies (Apollo Life Sciences, Bicon, Biodel Inc, Oramed Pharmaceuticals Inc) are currently developing their oral insulin products.
body_text.section: Oral Insulin ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Biodel, Inc. is developing an oral formulation of insulin (VIAtab) designed to be administered sublingually. In a Phase I study, VIAtab delivered insulin to the blood stream quickly and resembled the first-phase insulin release spike found in healthy individuals. The company claims that an oral insulin therapy would be more convenient than currently available injectable or inhalable therapies, and they expect that convenience to result in increased insulin usage among the currently underserved early-stage patients with type 2 diabetes, thus helping to create better long-term outcomes for that patient population.
body_text.section: Oral Insulin ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Oramed Pharmaceuticals, Inc. is currently conducting Phase IIb clinical trials of its oral insulin capsule, ORMD-0801 on 30 patients diagnosed with type 2 diabetes [246]. Oramed’s platform technology has two components: (1) A chemical make-up that protects insulin during passage through the gastrointestinal tract, and (2) Absorption enhancers so that insulin could be absorbed by the intestine. Oramed Pharmaceuticals, Inc. in phase I clinical trials, has demonstrated that its oral insulin is safe, well tolerated, and has consistently reduced glucose and c-peptide levels in patients [247].
body_text.section: Oral Insulin ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: An alkylated, PEGylated, amphiphilic insulin conjugate (HIM-2, Biocon Corp., India) increased oral formulation of insulin in dogs and has reached Phase II clinical studies [248]. One of the major challenges in biopharmaceutical development, therefore, continues to be the need for effective oral delivery systems and a number of different approaches have already been used to promote oral delivery of insulin [249].
body_text.section: Oral Insulin ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: The concept of developing insulin mimetics is a long established one, but recent years have seen important developments. For example, protein tyrosine phosphatases (PTPs) are enzymes that control signal transduction pathways, and inhibition of individual PTPs can result in activation of therapeutically relevant kinase cascades. Tyrosine phosphatase 1B (PTP1B) is implicated as a negative regulator of insulin receptor signaling, so small-molecule inhibitors of this enzyme are being investigated as potential insulin mimetics or insulin augmenting agents. Inhibition of PTP1B in muscle and liver, down-regulates insulin signaling, thereby improving insulin sensitivity [250]. These compounds have a low potential for hypoglycemia. A number of compounds synthesized [251] as well as isolated from various plants have been found to be potent inhibitors of protein tyrosine phosphatase 1B.
body_text.section: Insulin Mimetics ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: During the last decades, a large body of evidence has accumulated to suggest that organo-vanadium compounds exert various insulin-like effects in both in vitro and in vivo systems. These include their ability to improve glucose homeostasis and insulin resistance in animal models of type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus. In addition to animal studies, several reports have documented improvements in liver and muscle insulin sensitivity in a limited number of patients with type 2 diabetes. [252, 253]. Among these compounds, vanadium (IV) oxo bis(maltolato) was the first to be investigated for its higher potency over inorganic vanadium salts in eliciting insulin-like properties in both in vitro and in vivo systems [254]. There are some concerns about the potential toxicity of available inorganic vanadium salts at higher doses and during long-term therapy. Therefore, new organo-vanadium compounds with higher potency and less toxicity need to be evaluated for their efficacy as potential treatment of human diabetes.
body_text.section: Insulin Mimetics ::: Experimental Drugs in Development for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Gene-based therapy is an attractive therapeutic strategy that has emerged as an alternative to the traditional treatments of diabetes (e.g. injections of insulin and islet transplantation). This therapeutic approach has the potential to treat, cure and prevent diseases and, despite the limited boundaries to its application, is frequently highlighted as one of the most promising technologies of this century. The aim of gene therapy is the transfer of genetic material into diseased cells or tissues, allowing for the healthy phenotype to be recovered [255]. To this end, three basic elements are required: a profound knowledge of the disease pathogenesis; the genetic sequence of interest that might function as a target; and stable delivery systems providing the targeted tissues with the level of duration of the gene expression necessary to reproduce the desirable therapeutic effect [256].
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Type 1 and type 2 diabetes are two examples of very common polygenic and multifactorial diseases that, along with cancer, neurologic and other metabolic diseases, are ideal targets for gene therapy application, since they provide targets that include suppression of autoimmunity, restoration of insulin responsiveness, functional replacement of pancreatic islets and correction of vascular and nerve damage associated with prolonged hyperglycemia. In fact, the risk-benefit balance of gene therapy in diabetes seems to be superior when compared to all currently used treatments.
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: The first steps towards the application of this innovative therapy in type 1 diabetes were made soon after the cloning of the insulin gene, in the late 1970s. Since then, a plethora of non-insulin producing cells that are not targeted by the immune system for autoimmune destruction (e.g. gut K cells, hepatocytes, myocytes, muscle cells, fibroblasts, keratinocytes, pituitary and exocrine cells) have been used to transform into artificial insulin-producing substitute cells. As true β-cell surrogates, they should be able to synthesize, package and store insulin, according to the metabolic needs, as well as to precisely respond to the blood glucose levels and avoid lag time in the secretory response. To achieve this, the pro-insulin gene should be engineered in order to incorporate a specific mutated amino acid sequence recognized by the furin protease to produce mature insulin, since the β-specific endoprotease involved in the cleavage and maturation of insulin in β-cells is absent in non-β-cells [257–259]. A construct encoding this engineered cDNA can be expressed after gene-delivery using cell-specific promoters, viral vectors or nanoparticles [258, 259]. The use of synthetic promoters to regulate glucose-responsive insulin production may confer advantages to these therapies since they can partially override the unresponsiveness of these cells to glucose with physiological secretion of insulin. Indeed, a synthetic promoter library containing hepatocyte nuclear factor-1 (HNF-­1), a CAAT/enhancer-binding protein (C/EBP) response element and a glucose-­response element was screened and it was found that the promoter SP23137 is highly effective on the production and secretion of insulin in response to glucose [260]. Still, this therapeutic approach faces other limitations. For instance, the fold-­induction of insulin release achieved by these constructs is smaller than that of the islets and insufficient to normalize glucose after tolerance tests. Thus, one can question the capability of gene-therapy-constructed nonpancreatic tissues to keep a stringent control over blood glucose concentration similar to the one provided by functional β-cells.
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: In opposition to ectopic gene expression of insulin, transplantation of pancreatic endocrine lineages reprogrammed from other cell types for β-cell replacement is also a possible and promising option. For example, it was shown that ectopic expression of human neurogenin 3 (NGN3) and pancreatic duodenal homeobox-1 (PDX1) in bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells triggers pancreatic endocrine gene expression, notably insulin, glucose transporter 2 (Glut-2) and somatostatin, as well as other β-cell lineage-associated genes [261]. The systemic delivery of a PDX1 construct to the livers of streptozotocin (STZ)-treated mice, using a first generation adenovirus therapy vector, was also shown to induce the activation of the endogenous pro-insulin 2 gene in the liver. This resulted in increased levels of serum insulin, glucagon and somatostatin and decreased levels of blood glucose that, despite the transience of the adenoviral constructs, lasted for a period of 4–6 months [72]. The ex vivo transduction of adult human hepatocytes with PDX1 also resulted in the induction of several β-cell gene products, and, upon transplantation under the renal capsule of diabetic mice, these cells did ameliorate hyperglycemia for prolonged periods of time [262]. Of noteworthy is the fact that transplantation of STZ-­treated mice pancreas with PDX1-transduced adipose tissue-derived stem cells (ASCs) significantly decreases blood glucose levels and increases cell survival. Moreover, PDX1-ASCs were shown to be stably engrafted in the pancreas, to acquire a functional β-cell phenotype and partially restore pancreatic function in vivo [263]. More recently, the transcription factor NKX6 was also found to activate immature pancreatic markers, such as NGN3 and insulin gene enhancer protein 1 (ISL1), in human liver cells, and NKX6 in complementation with PDX1 was found to promote insulin expression and glucose-regulated processed hormone secretion in hepatic cells [264]. Another relevant study showed that NGN3/Betacellulin (BTC) gene delivery and overexpression in the pancreas of STZ-diabetic mice is also able to restore glucose-stimulated insulin secretion and reverse hyperglycemia in these animals, rendering the neo-islets with a transcription profile similar to that of pancreatic islets [265]. The treatment further normalized the hepatic glucose secretion, reversed ketonemia and restored the hepatic glycogen content similar to levels observed in nondiabetics.
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Type 1 diabetes is characterized by infiltration of autoreactive T-cells that mediate the destruction of pancreatic β-cells and, as such, several therapeutic approaches aim at controlling autoimmunity in this disease. One of these strategies consists of inducing and/or expanding regulatory T cells (Treg), more specifically of the Foxp3-­CD4﻿+-expressing Treg (Foxp3+Treg) population, which are potent immunoregulatory effectors that modulate T cell and antigen-presenting cell (APC) responses [266]. Deregulation of Foxp3+Treg has indeed been reported in diabetic patients [267] and described to result in systemic T cell-mediated autoimmunity in mice [268]. Administration of cytokines, such as IL-2 and TGF-β1 has been used to manipulate T cell-mediated autoimmunity since they play critical roles in the maintenance of and/or differentiation of Foxp3+Treg. This approach offers several limitations, including the half-life of these proteins in the serum and, as such, the need for repeated administrations. Thus, an alternative approach to this cytokine-based immunotherapy is an inducible gene therapy strategy, which allows for the expression of the transgene in vivo and obviates the need for production, purification, and storage of recombinant proteins. Indeed, it has been shown that the intramuscular injection of adeno-associated virus (AAV) encoding murine IL-2 and TGF-β, followed by a short pulse of IL-2, is sufficient to prevent β-cell autoimmunity and diabetes in non-obese diabetic mice by increasing the frequency of Foxp3+Treg without nonspecifically activating and/or expanding T cells and other effectors cells [269]. Another study demonstrated that the transfer of the gene encoding the anti-­inflammatory cytokine IL-4, using AAV vectors, directly to the pancreatic islets of non-obese diabetic mice prevents islet destruction by blocking autoimmunity, mainly through the maintenance of Foxp3+Treg [270]. Despite the benefits of the systemic expression of cytokines and other molecules by gene transfer to different tissues, the concern on the possible adverse effects resulting from this systemic expression on normal immune function remains unclear. These findings, however, suggest that gene therapy employing vectors that encode cytokines and other immunomodulatory proteins may also prove to be an effective and safe strategy to manipulate type 1 diabetes.
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Other promising targets of gene-based therapy of diabetes are glucagon-like peptide-­1 (GLP1) and angiotensin I-converting enzyme type 2 (ACE2). GLP1, an incretin hormone that regulates postprandial blood glucose levels, has been suggested for the treatment of type 2 diabetes given its insulinotropic action. However, this protein exhibits an extremely short half-life due to its rapid degradation by the dipeptidyl peptidase IV protease. Gene delivery of GLP1 is a way to overcome this problem and effective experimental therapeutics were indeed achieved. For instance, delivery of GLP1 cDNA, using chitosan nanocomplexes, driven by a cytomegalovirus promoter/enhancer, in Zucker diabetic fatty animals resulted in increased levels of plasma insulin and efficient clearance of the blood glucose in glucose tolerance tests, when compared to untreated animals [271]. Moreover, in vivo expression of GLP1 mediated by dsAAV vectors induces significant pancreatic β-cell proliferation, enhances β-cell mass and insulin secretion, and significantly delays the onset of hyperglycemia in db/db mice [272].
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Gene therapy using ACE2, which is thought to act as a negative regulator for the renin-angiotensin system that also exists in pancreatic islets, was also shown to be effective on glycemic control in diabetic mice. In 8-week-old db/db mice, overexpression of ACE2 in pancreas, through the direct injection of adenoviral vectors encoding ACE2 gene, showed improved fasting glycemia, enhanced intraperitoneal glucose tolerance, increased islet insulin content and β-cell proliferation, and reduced β-cell apoptosis, as compared to the control. These evidences point to ACE2 as a novel target for the prevention of β-cell dysfunction and apoptosis occurring in type 2 diabetes [273].
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Improvement of health condition and quality life of diabetic patients may also pass by the direct treatment of diabetic complications, such as neuropathy, renal damage, retinopathy, impaired wound healing and cardiovascular disease. One of the best examples for a possible gene therapy approach is proliferative diabetic retinopathy (DR). This pathology is the leading cause of blindness worldwide and is characterized by increased vascular permeability and retinal neovascularization [274–276]. The eye constitutes a privileged organ to assess the effectiveness of anti-­angiogenic therapies, since it is non-invasively available for imaging techniques that allow the study of progression of neovascularization. Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is considered a central player in the regulation of angiogenis, and, therefore, has been proposed as the therapeutic target for treatment of late stages of DR characterized by neovascularization. However, currently used therapeutic approaches targeting VEGF in DR carry several drawbacks. Some of the approaches, developed and clinically tested to reduce neovascularization in DR, include intravitreal injections of antibodies that bind to and block VEGF action and its receptors, such as Ranibizumab (Lucentis) and Bevacizumab (Avastin). However, intravitreal administration is associated with increased intraocular hypertension and inflammation, whereas intravenous injection was observed to have significant risks of thromboembolic events. Another disadvantage of these therapeutic approaches is the requirement of frequent and costly injections. Therefore, alternative therapies that silence VEGF, for example by the use of vectors carrying specific interference RNAs against VEGF, are considered as a new generation of more effective strategies [256, 277].
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Another good example for the promising use of gene therapy is diabetic critical limb ischemia, which is one of the leading causes of disability among diabetic patients and is the most common cause of non-traumatic amputation in diabetes. It is a disease manifested by diminished blood flow to the legs and appears to be associated, at least in part, with loss of cell and tissue response to ischemia, leading to impairment of the wound healing and angiogenic responses. A recent study using a diabetic model of critical limb ischemia have shown that intramuscular injection of an adenovirus encoding a constitutively active form of HIF-1α (the key regulator of cell response to low oxygen) into the ischemic limb of diabetic mice increases the recovery of limb perfusion and function, reduces tissue necrosis, rescues the diabetes associated impairment of circulating angiogenic cells, enhances endothelial nitric oxide synthase activation, and increases vessel density and luminal area in the ischemic limb [278].
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: In agreement with the previous study, several reports have been suggesting that HIF-1 deregulation, induced by high glucose, is directly associated with the loss of cell adaptation to low oxygen in diabetes [279–282], having serious consequences in various organs and tissues, including myocardial collateralization, wound healing, renal, neural and retinal functions. Of significance, some groups have been showing that impairment of the HIF-1 pathway under high glucose conditions may result from the increased availability of methylglyoxal [283, 284], which is a highly reactive by-product of glycolysis. Thus, a therapeutic approach based on the gene delivery and overexpression of glyoxalase 1 (GLO1), the rate-limiting enzyme in the detoxification of methylglyoxal, to diabetic injured tissues, would ameliorate the cell response to hypoxia in diabetic tissues. Indeed, GLO1 overexpression is able to stabilize HIF-1α [284], as well as to increase HIF-1 transactivation in response to low oxygen and high glucose conditions, contributing to increase the levels of VEGF, CXCR4 and stromal cell-derived factor-1 (SDF-1) [283], which are known to increase mobilization of endothelial progenitor cells, improve neovascularization and tissue repair.
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Other recent studies also showed that local sustained release of VEGF, using adenovirus vector-mediated gene transfer, accelerates experimental diabetic wound healing, by stimulating angiogenesis, epithelialization and collagen deposition [285, 286]. Administration of adenoviral VEGF together with Angiopoietin-1 (ANG-1) has also been shown to be an effective and a promising therapeutic approach in the treatment of diabetic myocardial injury after an acute hypoxic challenge, such as a heart attack. Preclinical data demonstrates the efficacy of ­co-­administration of adenoviral VEGF and ANG-1 in increasing angiogenesis, increasing heart collateral development and reducing ventricular remodeling in the infarcted diabetic myocardium [287].
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: Since obesity is associated with an increased risk of developing insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes, there has been great interest in the development of gene therapies for the control of obesity. Leptin gene therapy is one of the most exciting and promising approaches in this field. This has been achieved by two different systems based on the transfer of the leptin gene to muscles using viral vectors or enhanced electroporation [288]. Intracerebroventricular injection of recombinant AAV encoding leptin in rats consuming a high-fat diet (HFD) have shown that leptin treatment reduces food intake and blocks the HFD-induced increase in weight, adiposity and metabolic variables. Blood glucose was shown to be slightly reduced but within the normal range. Treatment with leptin significantly augmented uncoupling protein-1 (UCP1) mRNA expression in brown adipose tissue, indicating increased thermogenic energy expenditure [289]. Recently, it was also found that ­intracerebro­­ventricular and hypothalamic injection of recombinant AAV vectors encoding the leptin gene abolishes chronic hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia in animal models of diabetes [290]. Gene therapy approaches to enhance leptin supply locally in the hypothalamus, although unconventional, may offer an efficient anti-diabetic treatment able to prevent and mitigate both type 1 and 2 diabetes [291]. Another example of a molecular therapy for obesity-induced diabetes relies on the hepatic gene transfer of CPT1A, the key enzyme in fatty-acid β-oxidation, or its constitutive active mutant form CPT1AM, to high-fat diet-treated and genetically obese mice using AAV vectors. CPT1A and, to a greater extent, CPT1AM, enhance hepatic fatty-acid oxidation, reducing the liver triacylglyceride content in these animals. Obesity-induced weight gain, increase in fasting blood glucose and insulin levels, and augmented expression of gluconeogenic genes were also restored to normal only 3 months after AAV treatment, suggesting a protective action of both CPT1 forms against diabetes and obesity-induced insulin resistance [292].
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: The goal of the most current therapies for diabetes is to provide a tight glycemic control in all patients in order to minimize the significant complications associated with hyperglycemia. However, glucose management remains a difficult problem. Thus, the interest on gene therapy approaches that might replace the ongoing therapies and avoid the development of diabetic complications is increasing. The preclinical gene therapy studies mainly aim at developing strategies for insulin replacement and suppression of molecular pathways underlying the loss of β-cell mass and hyperglycemic complications. Given the efficacy of these approaches in animal models of diabetes, the possibility of bringing them into the clinic is becoming more real. Despite this, there are still several obstacles to overcome. One of them lays on the identification of gene delivery systems that combine a high efficiency in cell targeting and gene expression with the least immunogenicity. To date, both viral and nonviral vectors failed to meet all these requirements. Viral vectors do not completely satisfy biosafety concerns due to their immunogenecity and to the random integration of their genetic material into the host genome, whereas nonviral vectors present a low transduction efficiency and lack of cell specificity. However, many efforts are being made towards the development of a good gene transfer technology, which, in parallel with the increasing knowledge on the pathogenesis of type 1 and type 2 diabetes, makes gene therapy move closer to the clinic.
body_text.section: Gene-Based Therapies for the Treatment of Diabetes

body_text.text: The prevalence of diabetes has been increasing worldwide and is expected to continue to rise over the next 50 years [2, 293]. The accompanying increase in the prevalence of diabetes-related complications and the occurrence of diabetes among younger adults, children, and adolescents is likely to have a substantial impact on healthcare costs, with cardiovascular disease and other chronic complications of diabetes accounting for more than one quarter of all direct expenses [3]. Patients with diabetes should be followed closely to ensure that they achieve and maintain both glycemic and nonglycemic treatment objectives. Given the loss of 80% of β-cell function at diagnosis of diabetes, as well as the 50% prevalence of pre-­existing coronary heart disease at diagnosis, a more aggressive approach from the earliest stages of disease is clearly indicated [294]. A number of new therapeutic strategies have been introduced [85], and a large number of new compounds are in various stages of development for the treatment of type 2 diabetes [295] and this reflects the enormous impact of diabetes on public health.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Thus, new approaches for the treatment of diabetes and availability of a variety of innovative therapeutic strategies will improve quality of life in the near future. Prevention and major changes in lifestyle factors such as diet and physical exercise will also be needed to contain the growing burden of diabetes.

FIGREF0.text: Fig. 1: The process of islet transplantation (Illustration by Giovanni Maki) [22]

FIGREF1.text: Fig. 2: Sources of new β-cells for the treatment of type 1 diabetes. Type 1 diabetes results from the autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β-cells. A cure for the disease may lie in the development of techniques to replenish islet mass. Some researchers have already directed the differentiation of ES cells toward an endocrine (Ins+) cell. The potential exists for liver and nonendocrine pancreatic cells to be reprogrammed by gene transfer or growth factor treatments to produce and release insulin in response to glucose. Recent evidence has suggested that adult β cells are mitotically active and can replicate in response to increasing insulin demands. A complete understanding of the factors and signals that regulate this process could allow this innate ability to be controlled in patients with diabetes. Finally, cadaveric human islets represent a promising source of therapeutic β cells through transplantation. Immunofluorescence staining of a primary adult mouse islet is shown in the center (insulin appears red). Abbreviations: DE definitive endoderm, ES embryonic stem, Ins+ insulin-positive
